conclusion: Analyze the motion of the laser beam and the geometry of the semi-cylindrical transparent brick.
The radius of the semi-cylinder is r. The laser beam moves with a constant velocity v from point A to point C.
Light will emerge from the arc surface when the angle of incidence is such that the light refracts outwards.
The critical angle θc can be found using Snell's law: sin θc = 1/n.
The light will emerge from the arc surface when the angle of incidence at the point of incidence D along the arc is equal to or greater than the critical angle θc.
The distance AD where the light starts to emerge can be found using trigonometry: AD = r sin θc.
The laser beam moves from point A to point D at a speed v. The distance AD is r sin θc. The time t to move from A to D is given by: t = AD/v = r sin θc/v.
Substitute the critical angle: Since sin θc = 1/n, t = r * (1/n) / v = r / (n v).
The light will emerge from the arc surface ABC at the time: t = r / (n v).
